section.title: Performing the Upgrade from HPE Helion OpenStack 2.1 to 2.1.2
section.p: This update process requires that you have already upgraded to version 2.1. When upgrading from to you will use the same configuration files in your ~/helion/my_cloud/definition directory as you used when originally installing the software.

The configuration you specified will remain unchanged through the upgrade process; however, if you made any configuration changes by passing parameters to any Ansible playbooks using the -e option, you should find the affected files and make the required changes directly in the files in ~/helion/my_cloud and commit them to the git repository so that those changes are tracked and applied during the upgrade process. Otherwise they will not be applied after the upgrade.

You may also install as a full install. Those instructions are found in the installation guide. See Installation Overview for details. If you choose to do a fresh install it is important that you completely wipe your disk prior to doing the installation, otherwise errors may occur.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: These steps assume you have an installed and working cloud, and that you have followed the HPE Helion Development Platform upgrade process to gracefully shut down Helion Development Platform Services and instances.

ol.li:
Sign in and download the product and signature files at the links below:
HPE Helion OpenStack Files
HPE Helion OpenStack Signature Files
You can verify the download was complete via the signature verification process outlined here.

To begin the upgrade process, log in to the lifecycle manager as the user you created during the deployment, and mount the install media at /media/cdrom; for example: sudo mount Helion-OpenStack-2.1.2.iso /media/cdrom
Run the included initialization script to update the lifecycle manager: ~/hos-2.1.2/hos-init.bash

If you have made any made any changes to your configuration files, ensure that you commit them to your local git and if any merge conflicts are reported, you must resolve them before proceeding: cd ~/helion git add –A git commit –m "My changes"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Run the ready deployment playbook: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

ESX - additional step: If you are using the Entry-scale with ESX model you will need to uncomment the EON upgrade step from the YAML file below prior to continuing with the upgrade steps: ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible/_hlm-service-upgrade.yml
The line to uncomment is: eon-upgrade.yml

Get status of all your services, if desired cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-status.yml
If status comes back bad for any service, run the service reconfigure playbook, with naming convention <service>-reconfigure.yml, for that service, then run the status playbook for that service and see if the issue is resolved.
The status playbooks have this naming convention: <service>-status.yml
A full list is included at the end of this document.

Run the upgrade playbook (required for all models/deployments): cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-upgrade.yml You may see an Ansible code style warning: [WARNING]: It is unnecessary to use '{{' in conditionals, leave variables in loop expressions bare. If so, please ignore. You may run the hlm-status.yml playbook any time you like for status information.
ESX - additional step: Once the upgrade is complete, skip to the Further ESX Model Upgrade Instructions section.

section.title: Checking Version Updates
section.sectiondiv: To check to see if a node has been successfully updated on a control plane node, run from the lifecycle manager node to any other node via its IP address: : ssh <IP_address> cat /etc/HP_Helion_version | grep Helion The output should look like this: HP Helion OpenStack hos-2.1.2 (build 01-754)

sectiondiv.p: Once you have completed the initial upgrade instructions, you must follow these additional steps for ESX deployments:

ol.li: The new cluster import can be performed directly with the command below on the already activated Data center (DC): eon cluster-import --vcenter-id <vcenter-id> --cluster-name <cluster-name> --cluster-moid <MOID of cluster>

If the cluster activation is on a new DC, follow the steps below before performing the cluster-import: Provide the correct eth interface details for data_interface_order and trunk_interface_order parameters as per the defined input model. Refer to Register ESX Cloud Network Configuration for more details.

section.title: Get List of Status Playbooks
section.sectiondiv: Running the following command will yield a list of status playbooks: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ls *status* Here is the list: stack@helion-control-plane-cluster1-m1-mgmt:~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible$ ls *status* bm-power-status.yml eon-status.yml heat-status.yml logging-producer-status.yml monasca-status.yml rabbitmq-status.yml ceilometer-status.yml FND-AP2-status.yml hlm-status.yml logging-server-status.yml neutron-status.yml sherpa-status.yml ceph-status.yml FND-CLU-status.yml horizon-status.yml logging-status.yml nova-status.yml swift-status.yml cinder-status.yml freezer-status.yml ironic-status.yml memcached-status.yml ops-console-status.yml vsa-status.yml cmc-status.yml glance-status.yml keystone-status.yml monasca-agent-status.yml percona-status.yml zookeeper-status.yml
